AIA Articles.Article_Name: AIA praises Carbajal's Aerospace Caucus role
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: The Aerospace Industries Association is supporting for the decision to add Rep. Salud Carbajal, D-Calif., as co-chair of the House Aerospace Caucus. "As Democratic lead of the House Aerospace Caucus, Rep. Carbajal will be an asset to the Caucus' mission of maintaining America's enduring global aerospace leadership and addressing ongoing challenges faced by the aerospace industry," said Eric Fanning, AIA president and CEO.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: Army looks to accelerate software buys
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: Young J. Bangs, the US Army's principal deputy assistant secretary for acquisition, logistics, and technology, emphasized the need for the service to purchase software more rapidly than hardware to combat China's digitally native military. At the TechNetCyber conference, he also highlighted the importance of reducing electromagnetic signatures and modernizing data structures, warning that without these changes, the U.S. military's advanced equipment could become more of a liability than an asset against a technologically adept adversary like China.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: Raytheon explores potential of laser power transmission
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: The Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency has awarded a contract to Raytheon Technologies for the first phase of the Persistent Optical Wireless Energy Relay project, aimed at designing a high-altitude optical relay to create scalable on-demand power networks. The project's goal is to demonstrate optical power-beaming relays that can transmit energy from a ground source laser to 60,000 feet in altitude and back down to a ground receiver 125 miles away.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: Panel recommends changes to defense budget process
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: A congressionally mandated commission has released an interim report urging the Pentagon and Congress to reform the budget planning process, detailing 13 immediate improvements and 10 further suggestions pending stakeholder feedback. The recommendations include improved information sharing with Congress, consolidating budget line items, bolstering the Pentagon's budget management workforce, modernizing information systems, and streamlining budget data sets.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: Dubai Aerospace Enterprise selects Max for fuel efficiency
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: Dubai Aerospace Enterprise has entered into an agreement to acquire 64 Boeing 737 Max aircraft from China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings Limited, with deliveries scheduled between 2023 and 2026. The deal, which includes various models of the 737 Max, is part of DAE's strategy to develop a fleet for leasing, and it will increase the share of modern, fuel-efficient aircraft.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: P&W, Collins pursue electric flight breakthrough
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: During the 2023 Paris Air Show, Raytheon Technologies, along with Pratt & Whitney and Collins Aerospace, announced a significant milestone in their hybrid-electric flight demonstrator program, having successfully completed a rated power test of the electric motor. The program focuses on developing a high voltage distributed turboelectric hybrid-electric propulsion system.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: Atlas showcases Boeing Dreamlifter at air show
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: Atlas Air showed off a Boeing Dreamlifter at the 70th Experimental Aircraft Association AirVenture Oshkosh Airshow. "It was an amazing experience to share our passion with hundreds of thousands of other aviation enthusiasts," said 747 Fleet Captain Tom Vize.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: Women in Aviation offers $1M in scholarships
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: More than 105 scholarships valued at over $1 million will be offered by Women in Aviation International for its 2024 scholarship program, with applications now being accepted through a new online platform. Candidates can apply until Oct. 12, and scholarships in areas such as flight training, drones, engineering and professional development will be presented next March at the 35th annual Women in Aviation International Conference.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: GD, Leidos provide geospatial services to Army
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: Leidos and General Dynamics' One Source unit have been awarded a $99 million cost-plus-fixed-fee contract to continue providing geospatial services to the US Army. The services will be performed in support of the Army Geospatial Center, responsible for handling geospatial data, and the contract follows a previous five-year, $200 million agreement where the two companies contributed technical expertise to related Army programs.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: NASA, Sikorsky, DARPA advance air taxi automation
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: NASA's Advanced Air Mobility researchers, in collaboration with Sikorsky and the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, are working on developing and testing automation software for self-flying air taxis, focusing on safety and reliability. Utilizing specialized helicopters as substitutes for air taxis and advanced simulations with customized test-tablets, the team is able to recreate air-to-air encounters and simulate conflict scenarios, with NASA pilot Scott Howe affirming that the software has proven capable of "safely executing multiple precise software-controlled profiles in a single flight."

AIA Articles.Article_Name: Air Force likely to expect more data rights
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: New agreements granting the US Air Force access to technical data rights for the Lockheed HH-60W combat rescue helicopter and the Boeing MH-139A utility helicopter, represents a significant shift, allowing the service to maintain and modify equipment at a lower cost. Dan Grazier, senior defense policy fellow at the Center for Defense Information, argues that the use of these types of agreements will expand to other systems.
